com.qualcomm.snapdragon.sdk.deviceinfo

Class DeviceInfo

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.qualcomm.snapdragon.sdk.deviceinfo.DeviceInfo

  • public class DeviceInfo
extends java.lang.Object
    The DeviceInfo API provides a mechanism to query a device about the presence of certain functionalities. This is done in one of two ways: 1) As a set of course-grained methods providing information about the presence of commonly-requested device attributes 2) The Bundle returned by getSystemInfo() contains a super-set of information contained in the course-grained methods as well as additional attributes not available by calling standalone methods.

    Some Snapdragon features are implemented such that they enhance the standard Android APIs without any extra work from the developer. For these features the Snapdragon SDK provides detection methods through the DeviceInfo interface so that the application can detect the presence of the feature at run-time.

    For example, geofencing has been available in the Android platform since API level 1 as a software solution. But, on devices that support Qualcomm's hardware solution, applications can take advantage of geofencing that is lower in power consumption and also has improved responsiveness using the standard Android location APIs. In addition to geofencing, some Qualcomm-based devices have a hardware implementation of the the criteria-based positioning solution introduced in API level 10 of the Android API. Precise Indoor Positioning provides additional information in the Bundle returned by android.location.Location::getExtras() to registered LocationListeners provided that the device supports Qualcomm's indoor positioning.

    The location framework isn't the only place where this can be seen. In the media framework, some Qualcomm-based devices support Echo Cancellation Noise Suppression (ECNS) without requiring the developer to do anything other-than initiating a VoIP call. Finally, surround sound recording functionality is available on some Qualcomm devices using the standard AudioRecord APIs.

    Although it's possible to benefit from the presence of these features without doing any additional work, the DeviceInfo API provides run-time feature detection such that it's possible for an application to determine if it will need to fall-back to some other functionality in the event that it is executing on a device which doesn't come with support for these features out of the box. For example, an application developer may want to implement their own ECNS algorithm as a fallback. Feature detection is accomplished through the use of the isFeatureSupported(Features) method.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static java.lang.String KEY_SNAPDRAGON_DETECTED
      The key that will be used in the device info bundle to indicate whether the device has been detected as containing a Snapdragon chipset
      static java.lang.String KEY_SNAPDRAGON_DETECTED_CONFIDENCE
      The key that will be used in the device info bundle to indicate the level of confidence with which the device is believed to contain a Snapdragon chipset
      static int VALUE_HIGH_CONFIDENCE
      Constant value indicating that enough tests for the presence of Snapdragon passed to give high confidence
      static int VALUE_LOW_CONFIDENCE
      Constant value indicating that some tests for the presence of Snapdragon passed, but not enough for moderate or high confidence
      static int VALUE_MODERATE_CONFIDENCE
      Constant value indicating that some tests for the presence of Snapdragon passed, but not enough for high confidence

    • Method Detail

      • isSnapdragon

        public static boolean isSnapdragon()
        Method to determine, at run-time, whether the application is running on a Snapdragon chipset
        Returns:
        true if enough checks pass to confidently determine that the device uses a Snapdragon part; false otherwise

      • isFeatureSupported

        public static boolean isFeatureSupported(DeviceInfo.Features feature,
                         Context context)
        Method to determine, at run-time, whether a feature is supported on the device. Requires a valid application Context, which can be acquired by calling getApplicationContext from an Android Activity

        Sample Usage: 

         boolean isLowPowerGeoFence = DeviceInfo.isFeatureSupported(DeviceInfo.Features.FEATURE_LOW_POWER_GEOFENCE, this.getApplicationContext());

        Parameters:
        feature - the feature from DeviceInfo::FEATURE_LIST to check support for
        context - a valid android.content.Context object
        Returns:
        true is the requested feature is supported on the device; false otherwise

      • getDeviceInfo

        public static Bundle getDeviceInfo()
        Method to get more granular data about the underlying device As more functionality is expose through the API, additional keys may get added to the Bundle. Bundle::keySet() returns a collection of Strings that can be inspected for the presence of specific keys. Calling isSnapdragon() should be the first step to determine if the the underlying chipset is in-fact a Snapdragon. A false value can be considered trustworthy, but calling getDeviceInfo() will still return a Bundle with key KEY_SNAPDRAGON_DETECTED and a value of false. However, a true value should not be considered the final conclusion. Instead, as a second step, getSystemInfo() should be called and the bundle should be checked for the SNAPDRAGON_CONFIDENCE_LEVEL key. The confidence level will be one of the SnapdragonConfidence enum values.
        Returns:
        Bundle object containing device information
